stem: The nurse reviews the clinical data. Select the 3 most likely findings that require immediate attention based on the client's presentation.

options.text: Client reports feeling relief after rupture
Client reports pain in the right lower quadrant

tabs.name: SBAR
tabs.content: 07:00 - S: J.M., a 24-year-old male, presented to the ED with complaints of abdominal pain. The pain started approximately 12 hours ago around the umbilicus and has since localized to the right lower quadrant. He also reports nausea and has had one episode of vomiting. 07:05 - B: The client has no significant past medical history. He denies any allergies to medications, food, or environmental factors. He reports being in good health prior to the onset of these symptoms. 07:10 - A: The client appears to be in moderate distress due to pain. Physical examination reveals guarding and rebound tenderness in the right lower quadrant. Vital signs are as follows: Temp 38.5°C (101.3°F), HR 110 bpm, RR 22 breaths/min, BP 130/80 mmHg, SpO2 98% on room air. Pain is rated as 7/10. 07:15 - R: Suspect possible appendicitis based on the client's presentation and physical exam findings. Recommend immediate surgical consult and further diagnostic testing, including a complete blood count (CBC) and abdominal CT scan. Administer pain medication as prescribed. Monitor vital signs closely and assess the client's pain level frequently.

tabs.name: Vitals
tabs.content: Temperature: 38.5°C (101.3°F), Heart Rate: 110 bpm, Respiratory Rate: 22 breaths/min, Blood Pressure: 130/80 mmHg, SpO2: 98% on room air

tabs.name: Exam
tabs.content: Physical examination reveals guarding and rebound tenderness in the right lower quadrant. Abdomen is rigid and tender to palpation at McBurney's point.

tabs.name: Orders
tabs.content: NPO, IV fluids (Normal Saline) at 100 mL/hr, Morphine 4mg IV q4h PRN pain, CBC, Abdominal CT scan with contrast, Surgical consult

tabs.name: MAR
tabs.content: Morphine 4mg IV given at 07:30 for pain rated 7/10.

rationale.option_1: CORRECT: Rebound tenderness at McBurney's point is a classic sign of appendicitis due to peritoneal inflammation.
rationale.option_2: INCORRECT: Relief after rupture can occur, but indicates a serious complication requiring immediate intervention to prevent peritonitis.
rationale.option_3: INCORRECT: Generalized abdominal pain may be present early, but the pain localizing to the RLQ is more indicative of appendicitis.
rationale.option_4: CORRECT: An elevated white blood cell count of 15,000/mm³ indicates an inflammatory response, consistent with appendicitis.
rationale.option_5: CORRECT: Pain in the right lower quadrant (RLQ) is a hallmark symptom of appendicitis as the inflammation becomes localized.
rationale.option_6: INCORRECT: Constipation can be a symptom, but it is not as specific or critical as the other findings.

clinicalPearls: Appendicitis often presents with periumbilical pain that migrates to the right lower quadrant. Rebound tenderness at McBurney's point is a key finding. Elevated WBC count supports the diagnosis.
questionTrap: Be alert for distractors that are general symptoms of abdominal discomfort or less specific findings. Focus on the classic triad: RLQ pain, rebound tenderness, and leukocytosis.
mnemonic: McBurney's Point: Remember 'RLQ Pain' (Right Lower Quadrant Pain) - the hallmark sign. Also, consider 'WBC' (White Blood Cell Count) - Elevated WBCs indicate inflammation.
